ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A thorough introduction to WGSS faculty, community, and broader theories and methodologies.

This course was a rare opportunity to interact with people outside of my own discipline. While this sometimes resulted in me really appreciating the methods of my own field, I did appreciate hearing alternate perspectives, and found the shared struggles with having gender and sexuality topics taken seriously validating.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: while the presentations weren't always relevant to me, I appreciated the exposure to topics I might not have thought about otherwise. Weaknesses: I usually did not find the readings for the small group meetings particularly helpful, and definitely enjoyed the more open-ended meetings better. I think the course could very likely be improved by using the just-us sessions to talk about students' own experiences as WGSS scholars rather than to try to use such a small amount of time to try to learn about the field as a whole, which would likely work much better in a theory or WGSS-inflected history sort of class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I definitely experienced this course as a hoop-jumping kind of situation, but I would certainly recommend the certificate program to anyone interested in WGSS topics.
